content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												So, after having played Caster for a good while...What do I think of it?On my first time, I started and stopped the game due to controller issues, but it was likely a problem on my end. I'm unsure if it's accostumed to XInput or DirectInput... Anyway, the controls are pretty simple and fluid, since it's the basic move-shoot-jump combo with a Dash button. You have an upgrade system, in which you can up your shield (Lifebar), your pickup distance, Super Jump, Dash (which becomes really handy as you go on), along with the six weapons. The graphics are reminiscent of the early PS2 era, meaning that if your computer is the equivalent of a toaster you shouldn't have any problems running it. You have three difficulties - Casual, Normal, and Hardcore - that are all functional in their own way. You have a good bunch of levels, though the objectives are straightforward. The gameplay in itself feels like a cross between Megaman Legends and a Bullet Hell, when you have loads of enemies. The music has a touch of electronica, neither ill-advised nor well-suited, but it gets the job done. The story's pretty simple, as you're a completely new Caster trying to go up against an alien race known as Flanx. As usual, it's all up to you as you traverse through the game. As you power up your weapons, you're going to have to play a little bit differently as each weapon intensifies its use - as an example, Blast blows small craters on its first upgrade, developing into giant holes as you further upgrade. The scenery, as advertised, shifts along with the battles you have in the level, in a level of terraforming I haven't seen in any game of yet - reminding me a bit of the Dragon Ball Z series, in a way. It's not exactly a time-sinker, as it is Single-Player, but it's always good for a round or two if you're a little bit bored. It does have mods, but you need to go to the game's site to get them. At the time of this review, there's only one modpack - that assumes you have everything upgraded, as it ups the challenge. Perhaps if this game had enough of a fanbase, it might qualify for a Steam Workshop...?tl;dr - Forgettable if you let it slide back into your games library not to touch it, but your first playthroughs are decisively fun and entertaining, and likely enough to keep you entertained.4/5 - Gameplay3/5 - Sound3/5 - GraphicsFINAL SCORE:3/5 - Reasonable!

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												This game was boring right off the bat, but it seemed to be getting more interesting so I kept playing.  I finished the entire first campaign.  It actually managed to get worse.Nothing in this game is done well.  The combat requires no skill, just persistance.  Instead of actually ramping up difficulty, the designer just made a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of bullet sponges.  The various attacks and upgrade system are horribly imbalanced, with some things being almost completely useless.  For example, the stun ability has an incredibly short effect time.  The levels are horribly designed.   There was one level where the mission briefing told me to elmininate all the enemies while climbing what was essentially a huge spiral staircase around a tower.  It then allowed me to just run up the side of the tower, ignoring every enemy, and complete the mission by reaching the top.  Of course, I'm sure I don't need to tell you that it looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥too.  After all, you have eyes.I really cannot see how anyone would have terrible enough taste to reccomend this.  It's slow, easy, tedious, unoriginal, and ugly.It's trash.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Out of boredom I used the last coins in my wallet to buy this game, at first I was thinking it would be a terrible mistake, ironically, this game has potential, and got me playing it for 2 hours 'till I found it's end.The spells at their first levels aren't that interesting, but after farming those trees for a bit and unlocking more powerful levels, I found out that it's incredibly fun to blow several enemies with that acid blast spell while jumping several feet high and creating a massive hole on the ground at the same time. I think the development should continue, and maybe in the future this game can earn a sequel, or a revamp in these graphics, because it's really worth it. So to sum it up, I love this precious mini-game, but I'd love to see the full version of it.

Caster ReviewPro Tips:1) Upgrade dash and jump first!2) In the first level, hit all the trees and kill all the enemies! You should have a total of 6895 orbs!Caster is a good game for only 1.99. It’s definitely nothing great but you can definitely get some fun out of it. If your new to PC gaming and your not fully adjusted to keyboard controls this game is definitely a good place to start. This is an indie game so I don’t expect much from this game, but the graphics are nothing to cry home about. I understand the person was trying to go for a PS1 type look but it needs refinement. Also a story though not necessary would have helped this game out a bit. My final score is as follows.Final GradeB

Posted: May 8, 2016
												Out of boredom I used the last coins in my wallet to buy this game, at first I was thinking it would be a terrible mistake, ironically, this game has potential, and got me playing it for 2 hours 'till I found it's end.The spells at their first levels aren't that interesting, but after farming those trees for a bit and unlocking more powerful levels, I found out that it's incredibly fun to blow several enemies with that acid blast spell while jumping several feet high and creating a massive hole on the ground at the same time. I think the development should continue, and maybe in the future this game can earn a sequel, or a revamp in these graphics, because it's really worth it. So to sum it up, I love this precious mini-game, but I'd love to see the full version of it.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Steam Game Review: Caster     As many avid gamers out there know, Steam is an absolute must have when it comes to buying and/or sharing games and gaming experiences. There is an innumerable amount of content on Steam that can tickle the fancy of pretty much anybody out there. Among these games, is that of "Caster."     First, let's start with the basics. Pretty much any sale that Steam advertises on their 'Store' page, features this game. It's no more than a quarter (25 cents) every time a sale happens, so with that said, there really isn't too much reason NOT to get it. Let's face it, 25 cents really doesn't get you a whole lot nowadays as it is... You're lucky if you can get a giant gumball for that price at your local grocery store.     Caster is a neat little game that was developed by Elecorn, who is in turn an indie developer. With this said, one should definitely take into consideration the fact that the graphics won't be up to "par" as say a major developer's game (Bethesda, 2K Games, Activision, etc) would be. That's not to say that graphics are everything, however. The game does a great job of launching the player into this world that could be described as styled after an old Nintendo 64 3D platformer, much like Mario 64 or Banjo-Kazooie. Keeping this in mind, a controller adds to this nostalgic feel as the camera angles and movement work in much the same manner. Once the player goes through a brief tutorial mission, explaining how things work, the game then takes the player on a journey through a very outlandish world. It incorporates a rough combat system that puts a slowly unlocked arsenal of various lasers at the player's disposal. Each of these weapons serves a purpose on each level, and it's up to the player to use that noggin of theirs to figure out how each weapon applies to the current mission.     With the mention of weapons, and missions, there is a neat little "leveling up" system that happens as well. With each mission the player can destroy enemies and shoot trees to gain an in-game currency, which in turn let's the player upgrade various abilities as well as the lasers. These abilities include the ability to run faster or jump higher, for instance. Cool right? In fact, once some of these abilities are upgraded, the missions become a flatout breeze to go through in some instances. This could be looked at as a good thing, or a bad thing, depending on who the player is. That said, I'll leave that up to interpretation.      While nostalgia, loads of money to grab, and fun ways to outsmart the enemy are fun... This game falls short, and detrimentally so, in a few other, more crucial areas. First off, there is no real "story." This is absolutely key when it comes to immersing the player. Without a story... there's very little that will actually make the player feel as though anything is getting accomplished.     Another big problem with this game is the fact that the enemies are almost static in a sense. They have no real movement styles and the ability to decimate them by the thousands is absolutely comical. There's no real combat mechanics that the player needs to acquire in order thwart the enemy and whatever threat they pose in this distant place where nobody seems to know what's going on. This, in and of itself, can absolutely destroy the experience.     So... we have lots of guns, a "leveling" system, nostalgia that is offset by lack of story and no real challenge. The bad can offset the good, or vice versa. And maybe it wouldn't be all that bad if that was all there is to the story, however, it's not. Speaking of "all there is to the story," this game, above all things, is NOT COMPLETE. Judging by the looks of things, it won't ever be completed by the developer. This poor little gem of a game has been left incomplete for quite some time now (years, in fact) and the developer has yet to blink an eye at it. It's really quite a shame too, because there is so much potential here. All it needs just a little TLC and just a bit of polishing and this game could turn out to get the recognition that it (potentially) deserves. But don't hold your breath.     On a sidenote, however, I would like to include the fact that the developer was courteous enough to include an actual mission editor and level designer that allows players to fill in holes or create a whole new world. I have tried the editor out, and while it is somewhat wonky at first, I am highly appreciative that Elecorn allowed for the followers of the game the ability to take things into their own hands, if need be. In fact, there is also a section on the Caster/Elecorn website that allows for community submissions to be downloaded by the public to play. So... at least the "DLC" is free.     Taking ALL of this into account, I enjoyed my time with the game. And for only 25 cents, I enjoyed it even more. Given that it might take some imagination on the player's part to keep things going, it's well worth the small donation to try. That is... if you are willing to overlook the terribly awful state the game was left in.(Here's to hoping that at some point in time Elecorn revisits this 'pound puppy' of video games gives it the attention that it deserves.)For more information on Caster or download the game, please visit:http://www.elecorn.com/caster3d/index.htmlBe sure to check out my other content!YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9wBb1EsrvF6mEPTWD1d0qABlog: http://btngaminggamereviews.blogspot.com/Tumblr: http://bringthenoisegaming.tumblr.com/Follow me on Twitter: @BTN_Gaming

Posted: October 2, 2015
												A tech demo.  Bad graphics.  Good EDM music.  Repetitive gameplay: collect this, kill that.  You get different weapon power-ups.  Deformative terrain.  Upgrade system for weapons, health, speed, and jump.  15-20 stages; completes in about 2.5 hours.  Each stage is at least unique.  3 Environments: grass, snow, lava.  Last level is a "to be continued" but the game seems to have been abandoned/dropped/given up.Do not recommend.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												This game was on sale for $0.14 so I bought this game for cards but when I started playing it, I just couldn't stop ! Despite the poor graphics, this game is incredibly fun :D The environments keeps getting interesting as you progress, the terrain being affected during combat, the electronic background music and other stuff perfectly bind together the game. The gameplay is easy and quite smooth, killing bug-like things running at you, exiciting terrains, vaious attacks and upgrades and several other factors will add hours to your gameplay :)On the flip side, it has some cons too. It lacks some strategy and variety. The game is very short and the levels got only a few enemies, and it also seems that the developers spent more time on the environments rather than the characters. Overall, this game is awesome ! Worth a buy, especially if it goes on sale. I would rate this game 8.5/10 :)

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Dated and UnengagingCaster feels, in every way, like a game I might've rented for Nintendo 64 back in the day and completely forgotten about by the time the weekend came to an end.Clocking in at about an hour, the game is incredibly brief and simplistic--loosely guided by a storyline so insufficient it's difficult to understand what is actually going on, you dash across barren landscapes for a couple of minutes to fulfil what is usually one of two objectives: kill all flanks on the map or collect all energy balls on the map.The energy balls act as a currency enabling you to upgrade your shield, dash and jump abilities, as well as your arsenal of six weapons, which along with the rudimentary environmental deformation adds a little variety to the game. Regardless, I solely used the Blast weapon throughout the first campaign because none of the others ever offered any advantage. The second, shorter campaign simultaneously makes Caster more interesting and frustrating, posing more thoughtful objectives and stronger enemies yet forcing you to use useless weapons such as the Seeker, whose supposedly "seeking" missiles hit their target about 10% of the time.Frankly, this game wouldn't have made it past the bargain bin back on the Nintendo 64, and thus it's embarassing to see such an incredibly amateurish product released in 2009, indie or not, at the laughable price of 4.99. The fact that the second campaign still leaves you with a "to be continued" message, five years on, is telling of the fact that Caster has likely been abandoned, and rightly so.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												In this Dragonball inspired game, you play as a 'rookie caster' who is the only one left to restore the world and defend against the infestation known as the Flanx. This game will have you dashing about at high speeds blasting enemies and altering terrain with several different abilities. Launching this game the player's eyes will be assaulted with a fuzzy polygonal mess and a crudely conceived UI design. The nicest piece of art this game has to offer is the Steam thumbnail. Having bad production value doesn't mean a game isn't fun but unfortunately Caster has very little to offer in terms of gameplay. Caster is a third-person shooter with a camera angle that can very from directly behind the player-character to a top down perspective.  It can be fun to zip around the map and lay waste to enemies but the player won't experience this until at least one hour into the game. Caster requires the player to collect energy in order to upgrade abilities and as a result the first hour or so of gameplay is very slow and tedious. After this first hour there will be a brief moment of mild amusement and then the player is immediately introduced to enemies and situations that require a slower playstyle. In my opinion the developers would have done well to skip the whole upgrade process that made the first hour or so of gameplay a waste of time and focus on high speed gameplay that this game advertises. Just shy of two hours, my gameplay experience was ended by getting killed because my character was held motionless for a cutscene. This happened to me two consecutive times. This game supports USB controller gameplay however the controls seemed pretty bad (and maybe unworkable). I played with the keyboard and mouse. Score: 2/10

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Product received for free
												I got this for free and I still feel cheated.• The visuals. Textures look like they've been pulled from the 90s. Maps are big, floating rectangles with some hills here and there, surrounded by invisible walls. Trees were probably added ten minutes before the deadline. UI, well, exists, and that's the best I can tell about it.• The mechanics. Camera movement is a joke. Above you it doesn't show anything useful, and behind you it distorts the distance between you and your goal. Enemies can jump bazillion metres in the air and you cannot aim at them. But they can still hit you. You can upgrade your skills for credits, but the game doesn't tell you how will it affect them. For example, first upgrade for "dashing" (basically sprint) made it last 10 seconds instead of 1.• And the other stuff. Dashing makes you glued to the terrain like trucks in Big Rigs. That means you can climb terrain even at 90 degrees. Tutorial tells you, as an ADVANCED tip, that there are graphics options unavailable from settings menu and YOU HAVE TO MANUALLY EDIT CONFIG to access them. Pathetic.Overall: 1/10. I feel like I've put more effort into this review than devs into the game. Disgusting.

Quick breakdown below:Graphics - The graphics might seem a little off-putting at first, but I quickly got over it as soon as I got into the gameplay. The character textures and models could definitely use a lot of work though.Gameplay - It's got a retro feel to it. That is, a lack of premise, but immersive gameplay. If you're looking for something with a storyline, you'll be disappointed. I've only played through the game on normal difficulty, but even then there were some stages that surprised me (in a good, challenging sort of way). Camera/controls are *occasionally* fidgety, (egs. running on walls in certain maps can be pretty trippy) but it's never enough to really detract from the game. Replay value is so-so. Ending indicates a game that its creators no longer wanted to invest money/time into.Audio - Hit-and-miss for me. Some tracks are amazing, and really go well with the action, others just sound like cheap techno tracks.Mods - Rather than mods, I'd call them user-created stages. Downloaded a mod-pack off the game's website, and had a lot of fun with those.All in all, I got about 3 hours of gameplay from this. Thoroughly enjoyed this, my only major complain being the lack of content (in terms of stages). Maybe there are more mods in forums, but I have not looked at those yet.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Caster is third-person shooter where the player controls an inexperienced hero. This hero descends from a rare lineage of people with extraordinary abilities that interact unusually with both the terrain and the plants that sprout from it. The player is employed by an organization to eliminate an incursion of beasts known as the Flanx, bug-like monsters that dwell in water, land, and air. I've beat this game a total of 16 times, doing someting different each time. I wanted to see if there was a different outcome in the end, but it still feels like the ending level is the most difficult, and the only challenging. Getting this game for $0.17 was probably my best idea yet.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												This game is consistently available for under 20 cents.It's not great, but it does two things exceedingly well that are rare features in many other games, AAA or indie:1) Fairly impressive terrain destruction. Instead of handling destructible terrain in the traditional way of having set destructible parts of the environment which will explode in a physics-based manner, Caster just creates entire levels out of fully terraform-able terrain. It's easy to create dents, craters, hills, and mountains out of the world around you on a whim, and that feels pretty cool.2) Empowering movement. Your character has two big movement abilities which make it very easy to cover huge distances in short time. There's a "super jump," which behaves like a double jump with absurd height to it, and a dash ability which increases movement speed, and allows you to run on water and up any walls. It feels fantastic and I haven't played with anything quite like it before.Outside of those two features, Caster is pretty dull. The combat, music, aesthetics, graphics, and general polish are all sorely lacking. That said, if you can spare fifteen cents and fifteen minutes, I'd recommend checking this game out for just long enough to experience how fluid and satisfying it is to run around in this game's world.

If you're looking for some frantic action and can look past the graphics being a little dated, can't do much better than this!

Posted: June 23, 2015
												I have to say "No" to this game. Sure I got it for 14 cents, but that was on the Steam Summer sale, usually it's $3 and I can't recommend this game for $3. Some history. I first played Caster when it first came out on the IOS in 2009. I had a fun time, but was dissipointed when I got a "To be Continued" screen. Imagine my excitement now in 2015 when I could pick up the game again 6 years later! Sadly, it did not hold up in the years. No progress has been made to the game whatsoever. I checked the guys website and while this is a side project, he seems to have started working on other things. I found 2 "update" posts on updating caster in the past 3 years, but so far nothing has changed. I feel like the person who made this game just wants to move on and this game will never be finished.Story wise it's meh. You are a Caster which are people who fight against creatures called the Flux. You are coming out to be a prodigy, and are a great asset to the Caster Community with your help in the research of Nega Orbs. That's where it ends because the game isn't finished. It's an interesting concept, but it's not execute to its full potential. 3/10Graphics wise, its decent. The enviroments are nice considering its very basic. A few issues I had are mostly with the main character. He looks horrible. While from behind it's ok, his face is terrifying I couldn't help but be pulled away from the experience everytime I saw his messed up eyes and weird smile. I really would want to change it. Also his animation cycles are also meh. With his run and jump being but faster or holding it, I feel it could have been approached diffrently. 5/10Music is pretty good. Honestly if it wasn't for the music, this game would be way more lacking. It's good electronic for the setting. Nothing else to really say about it. 7.5/10Gameplay is mixed. At first, you start off pathetically weak as the first 2-3 missions are a challenge. But then Early Mid game becomes fun as you level up your abilties. You actually feel very powerful with the destruction of the envirmont, almost godlike. However, later on the game falls off. Missions are repeated, just in diffrent stages. Enemies either take way to many hits for the "powerful" feeling. Or they are impossible to hit like the flys. No joke, I spent a good 10 minutes trying to kill a group of flys, because the only way to hit them is with the seeker power, and even that it's almost impossible. Creature design was pretty fun, I especially like the battle with the flux that would grab you and slow you down, but most of the enemies are boring. The one's that really do shine are the bosses and the creatures with abilities like yours. The game also moves to fast for it's own good. I had a hard time being able to hit enemies because I had to run at max speed dodging bullets while I tried my best to charge and fire my shots. Also most of the abilities are kinda worthless. The blue laser, the seeker and the land destory abilites are the only real abilities you should put into besides one mission were you need to use the land build up to move a orb to the other end. 5/10Final Verdict 5.5/10. It's a fun game that you can play to burn up an hour or so. But I can't recommend getting this game at the full $3. It's a bit weird and won't keep you invested and finally, you will never see this game finished most likely.

Posted: October 1, 2015
												Well.... I have no idea what I expected for 14 cents but dang it really was something.Basically the map and graphics look like something from the N64/PS1 era except slightly more crudely made. (A rough 3D map tool basically) From there you take the speed of Sonic, the jumping ability of Moon Shoes on a Pogo Stick, the physics of Big Rigs, awesome mech warrior/magic powers, the landscaping tool from Rollercoaster Tycoon and combine  them into one game. And it is just... a once in a lifetime experience. Other then that, the game has some variety in missions, enemies, and things to do albeit very easy even on normal and "extreme" difficulties. For 14 cents... Yea, I'd go for it. It's something to remember.

You'll find yourself having to change the face of the terrain in several levels in order to accomlish your objectives. I'd say more, but I don't want to give too much away.I hope the developers of this game go on to bigger and better things. I checked the guys website and while this is a side project, he seems to have started working on other things. I found 2 "update" posts on updating caster in the past 3 years, but so far nothing has changed. I feel like the person who made this game just wants to move on and this game will never be finished.Story wise it's meh. You are a Caster which are people who fight against creatures called the Flux. You are coming out to be a prodigy, and are a great asset to the Caster Community with your help in the research of Nega Orbs. That's where it ends because the game isn't finished. It's an interesting concept, but it's not execute to its full potential. 3/10Graphics wise, its decent. The enviroments are nice considering its very basic. A few issues I had are mostly with the main character. He looks horrible. While from behind it's ok, his face is terrifying I couldn't help but be pulled away from the experience everytime I saw his messed up eyes and weird smile. I really would want to change it. Also his animation cycles are also meh. With his run and jump being but faster or holding it, I feel it could have been approached diffrently. 5/10Music is pretty good. Honestly if it wasn't for the music, this game would be way more lacking. It's good electronic for the setting. Nothing else to really say about it. 7.5/10Gameplay is mixed. At first, you start off pathetically weak as the first 2-3 missions are a challenge. But then Early Mid game becomes fun as you level up your abilties. You actually feel very powerful with the destruction of the envirmont, almost godlike. However, later on the game falls off. Missions are repeated, just in diffrent stages. Enemies either take way to many hits for the "powerful" feeling. Or they are impossible to hit like the flys. No joke, I spent a good 10 minutes trying to kill a group of flys, because the only way to hit them is with the seeker power, and even that it's almost impossible. Creature design was pretty fun, I especially like the battle with the flux that would grab you and slow you down, but most of the enemies are boring. The one's that really do shine are the bosses and the creatures with abilities like yours. The game also moves to fast for it's own good. I had a hard time being able to hit enemies because I had to run at max speed dodging bullets while I tried my best to charge and fire my shots. Also most of the abilities are kinda worthless. The blue laser, the seeker and the land destory abilites are the only real abilities you should put into besides one mission were you need to use the land build up to move a orb to the other end. 5/10Final Verdict 5.5/10. It's a fun game that you can play to burn up an hour or so. But I can't recommend getting this game at the full $3. It's a bit weird and won't keep you invested and finally, you will never see this game finished most likely.

												Psychedelic masterpiece owing a debt to the Serious Sam school of fast-paced game design. Solid colors rammed through the bleariest of lighting filters. Megaman running and gunning on the transforming terrain of ExciteTruck, a 3D shooter spiritually in tune with by-gone arcade shooters. Flashbacks of Ratchet and Clank: Going Commando and the Jak and Daxter games but with a DIY cell-shaded anime aesthetic. On max settings, it is all bold tones smeared in radioactive light. Tune in, turn on, and be taken in the soft parade of energy orbs.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												A good game for the price. I greatly enjoyed the sense of speed and aerial freedom (even if it is clumsy at times) as well as the competently-arranged difficulty curve and the open level design. The combat is alright, although sometimes you have to fight with the camera to get it to look at where you want it to.The only thing I hate about this game is the length. I like the idea of being able to terraform and fight things in wide open environments, but the game can be finished in a couple of hours. I'm left with a concept that's well-executed but too short for it to fully explore its own mechanics. If you can overlook the length, this is a decent game.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												There are some GREAT ideas, and some terrible execution.First is terrain deformation, at first you think COOL! they figured it out, that's awesome. However, in reality the game is using auto generated planes as 'terrain'. and the deformation is either a + or - in height. There is NO other detail or deformation other than height. The texture is low quality, and doesn't deform with the mesh, so you get stretched and grainy textures all over the place. In addition to this, the tiniest 'down' deformation on an otherwise flat area will trap your character, stopping you in your tracks. Super annoying, and a tip that the terrain is calculated as a series of boxes, instead of a mesh (lets stack boxes under a blanket, and ignore the fact that you run into the box and can't move, despite the blanket still being flat).Second is the mouse controls. Do you really expect anyone to play at such a low mouse movement speed? I'm REALLY glad I've got a G9x where I can adjust sensitivity on the fly. The menus are great on my 'normal' but at this speed it takes 6 swipes across my XXL mousepad for me to look in a circle. I adjust it up once, and it takes 3... which is reasonable. Then there is the fact that you start each level staring at your feet. You can move like normal in this view, which caused my death in the training... I was shooting my feet the entire level. AND this is the normal start for EVERY level.Lastly, Powerups are cool, but the default 4 are the obvious choices. "oh, I can pull money from the entire map if I level up this one first?... nah, I'ma go with leveling up a weapon first." The lack of damage counters, or additional effects also makes any weapon upgrades underwhelming. With just a little bit of effort, this one could be stricken off my list of complaints.LAST WORD:decent repetitive gameplay. Try it out if you must, but get it on sale when you can.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												I do not see any real reason this game should have bad reviews other than personal expectations being set too high.Right now it is 20 cents, I bought this game back when I first got my account, I still buy copies to give away or to encourage a trade.The simplistic nature of the levels pairs well with the arcade feel to the platforming action shooting gameplay.Yes the graphics are kind of oldish, but why complain, you play on PC... everything back to the text adventures can be had on your super rig, not just the hyper 3D flare.Really, you just blast stuff and upgrade your weapons.  The ability to morph the terrain is just great, and really reminded me of my time spent digging holes through levels in the first Red Faction.If you liked Mega Man 64, or maybe P.N.03 you really can't go wrong with a low requirement 20 cent title like this.A game like this EASILY could have been in an arcade, 25 cents a go.Like I said, the only real reason for a negative review from anyone boils down to their personal expectations, even if the game ends up feeling a bit like a work in progress, it works and it is fun.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												I have to say "No" to this game. Sure I got it for 14 cents, but that was on the Steam Summer sale, usually it's $3 and I can't recommend this game for $3. Some history. I first played Caster when it first came out on the IOS in 2009. I had a fun time, but was dissipointed when I got a "To be Continued" screen. Imagine my excitement now in 2015 when I could pick up the game again 6 years later! Sadly, it did not hold up in the years. No progress has been made to the game whatsoever. I checked the guys website and while this is a side project, he seems to have started working on other things. I found 2 "update" posts on updating caster in the past 3 years, but so far nothing has changed. I feel like the person who made this game just wants to move on and this game will never be finished.Story wise it's meh. You are a Caster which are people who fight against creatures called the Flux. You are coming out to be a prodigy, and are a great asset to the Caster Community with your help in the research of Nega Orbs. That's where it ends because the game isn't finished. It's an interesting concept, but it's not execute to its full potential. 3/10Graphics wise, its decent. The enviroments are nice considering its very basic. A few issues I had are mostly with the main character. He looks horrible. While from behind it's ok, his face is terrifying I couldn't help but be pulled away from the experience everytime I saw his messed up eyes and weird smile. I really would want to change it. Also his animation cycles are also meh. With his run and jump being but faster or holding it, I feel it could have been approached diffrently. 5/10Music is pretty good. Honestly if it wasn't for the music, this game would be way more lacking. It's good electronic for the setting. Nothing else to really say about it. 7.5/10Gameplay is mixed. At first, you start off pathetically weak as the first 2-3 missions are a challenge. But then Early Mid game becomes fun as you level up your abilties. You actually feel very powerful with the destruction of the envirmont, almost godlike. However, later on the game falls off. Missions are repeated, just in diffrent stages. Enemies either take way to many hits for the "powerful" feeling. Or they are impossible to hit like the flys. No joke, I spent a good 10 minutes trying to kill a group of flys, because the only way to hit them is with the seeker power, and even that it's almost impossible. Creature design was pretty fun, I especially like the battle with the flux that would grab you and slow you down, but most of the enemies are boring. The one's that really do shine are the bosses and the creatures with abilities like yours. The game also moves to fast for it's own good. I had a hard time being able to hit enemies because I had to run at max speed dodging bullets while I tried my best to charge and fire my shots. Also most of the abilities are kinda worthless. The blue laser, the seeker and the land destory abilites are the only real abilities you should put into besides one mission were you need to use the land build up to move a orb to the other end. 5/10Final Verdict 5.5/10. It's a fun game that you can play to burn up an hour or so. But I can't recommend getting this game at the full $3. It's a bit weird and won't keep you invested and finally, you will never see this game finished most likely.

Posted: April 27, 2015
												A pleasant surprise, I bought this game only because of the trading cards, but this was actually fun to play. The main reason why is that this game feels like a really fresh and original PS1 game. The core elements of the game make it fun to mess around with.In particular once you start upgrading dash you start running around like sonic the hedgehog. Dashing is pretty versatile too, you can run up and along hills very easily.The main thing that makes the game fun is being able to morph the terrain, in particular you can increase or decrease the height of terrain (within limits) which makes this game so fresh.Some of the levels really take the core concepts to heart to create really unique missions.The only bad thing I can say about this game is the beginning is really weak and the game is short. There are community made levels, but I didn't bother with them. And with the game being so old I doubt the devs are actively working to finish the game.Weirdly, this game is probably one of the better purchases I've ever made.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												For the little I spent for this game, I did not expect to have such frantic fun throughout my short playthrough. Reminiscent of a budget GunValkyrie crossed with a bit of MegaMan. While you start out very week and vulnerable, within a few levels your character becomes a map jumping, earthshaping war machine that somehow surpasses the multimillion dollar budget that Fracture had, as awful as that game was.That being said, even with a decent amount of levels, you'll be able to collect just about everything and wipe out the main story within a couple hours. The real meat is found in community made maps, but by the time I got there the game had lost its draw as I had seen just about all I was going to see.The combat is fairly fluid, and a variety of weapons with multiple functions offering your preference of extermination. There are some extremely basic puzzles, and a good handful of secrets, all adding up to upgrading your tools, but once you max everything out, that's it. The rest is just for personal achievement. You can always start a new game on a higher difficulty, but there isn't any bonus content that I could percieve. I've poured hundreds of hours into vacant games and came away with only the ghost of fun, but this, for the short time it offers it, is a more genuinely fun experience, and left me wanting more. While the late game levels were a bit more tedious than anything else, I was engrossed in reviving trees and blowing holes in the earth. For a sale or even for its base price, Caster is a short and charming experience that definitely struck a cord with me. A game that even without the story and collectables is a blast to play, and really, isn't that what made a lot of us fall in love with games to begin with?

Posted: March 29, 2015
-=Serious Review=--tl;dr reviewCaster is a perfect metaphor for the gaming industry as of writing this review. Caster represents an awesome idea that actually works and has only one real flaw with it, and that's how it's just too easy (Even so, that's eay to fix.) However, because of its unique style, it will not truly achieve the praise it needs. It's also unfortunate that the game has been essentially discontinued. That doesn't mean the community can't take it up on their own to continue it.-What is Caster? What genre does it fit into?Caster doesn't truly fit into the predefined genres we have today, the closest similar game would be Borderlands. It's definitely a shooting game, and also has some RPG elements. I guess we can call it an FPRPS (First Person Role-Playing Shooter.) It's third-person perspective and simple graphics also gives it that PS1/Arcade feel to it, and it's definitely appealing. Plus it easily gets 60+ fps on even the most burnt potato out there, so anyone can enjoy it.-StoryThere isn't much to the story, but the story that is there is enough... barely. All you're truly given is a name to the main enemies and some minor exposition. Basically, not a lot of text boxes.-GameplayThis is where Caster truly does shine. To start off, your character has free roam over wherever you are. As such you are given the ability to dash and super jump (which is a powerful double jump) to enhance the fun of it. With the base dash and jump, you're not moving very far or going very high, but as you upgrade you become more epic. Eventually you'll be dashing for longer distances, running on water, and even running on walls. I'll be damned if I could find another game that makes wall-running and shooting both fun and easy.When you start off, you'll only have your basic shooting "ability" "Pulse." It's not very strong starting out looking and behaving very similar to Mega Man's basic attack. It needs to be upgraded to become even better. Missions are where you earn the credits to upgrade this ability. And as you do more missions you'll gain access to more abilities, each with their unique-ness.Environment interaction. For a game off this size, it's incredible to have environments that are fully interactable. A lot of things can cause craters to form, from both you and enemies. If you super jump and fall long enough, you can leave a small crater and create a shockwave. Your basic shots can build craters too. You can even get an ability to create hills, to get bonuses underwater mainly. There's even one instance where enemies will try to stay underground and take pot shots at you.Enemies, however, is the only true point where the game doesn't shine. The enemies in Caster are way too easy. Upgrades for abilities just do massive amounts of damage, and enemies don't get adjusted for this in each level as you progress. Eventually, even on hard, you'll get to a point where you're just like: "That's cool, and now it's dead. Next level." It's a damn shame too, because adaptive enemies would pad out the gameplay much better than spreading them out. Too bad that'll never be fixed :c-tl;dr gameplaySonic the Hedgehog + Mega Man + Borderlands - Difficult AI = Caster-ModdingWhile I'm not truly a "Modder" (At the time of writing, at least) Caster looks way more than simple to mod. There is mod support from what I can tell at the time of writing this. I would also wager that this game would be a perfect start for getting into modding, as it's so simple and open to the idea of community-created content. Hell, why stop at making single-player campaigns? You could probably add some sort of multiplayer to this game easier than any other indie game on Steam. This might be where the game has a future, and it would be up to the community.

Posted: March 29, 2015
												Caster has some cool ideas, like weapons that deform the terrain and have multiple modes. The sense of speed you get (once you get Dash past level 1) is also pretty cool.However, the game looks primitive, if functional, and the missions seem incredibly dull. Admittedly, I only did about 10 missions, but the environments weren't interesting and the objectives were overly simple. Enemy AI is awful. There's a blob that literally does nothing unless you run into it (it doesn't even move), and some kind of walking worm thing that you just stunlock by hitting it every few seconds. On top of that, all the enemies are bullet sponges.Any fun you get from the sense of running around at ludicrous speeds is undermined by the fact that all you really do is circle-strafe and pump shots into bullet-sponge enemies. If you stop moving, you die quickly. The sense of speed is appealing for a few minutes, but that's about it. There are no checkpoints in missions, and most of them involve a lot of running through bland landscapes.

Posted: March 25, 2015
												Caster is kind of addicting. I think I got it for about 14 cents on sale, and figured for that low, it was worth a play. Caster is notably a small indie game, but the low graphics and minecraft-reminiscient maps aren't enough to take away from the addictive, and impressive gameplay. You jump around all over, and dash, all while attacking with very satisfying weapons, each with their own twist and turns, and most with an alternate fire. The combat is fast-paced and legitimately exciting, and the upgrades eventually make combat a breeze. The difficulty curve is all over the place on this one, but it's still fun to pick up and play for a while.

Posted: March 25, 2015
												I have loved this game a lot, playing 6.8 hours so far. It's very origional to me, while the graphics are not amazing, they don't really need to be since the gameplay itselt is all that should matter in a game good enough that you could take it and play it anywhere on any computer or laptop. The powers are amazing, shaping the land with these powers is both awesome, and hilarious at times. The story is easy enough to understand, nothing spectacular, but enjoyable as a classic tail of a sort of clan that happens to be good at fighting monsters and a new caster that rises up to meet the challenges. I loved the final boss fight from the first chapter, the boss was unique and quite a shocking unexpected surprise to me, I was not prepared, but happy to say I was satisfied with the challenge it was a good, somewhat difficult boss fight. I hope that the second chapter will be finished soon and that the game will get an amazing climax. My only minor dislike, proboably more personal than anything else, is lack of character creation. A little customization would be nice, or perhaps some character skin packs at the very least would be appreciated. Something so people are  not just picking male or female. Not that's it's nessisary, but it would be appreciated. Thank you for making a wonderful game, please continue with it.

Posted: March 29, 2015
												Caster has some cool ideas, like weapons that deform the terrain and have multiple modes. The sense of speed you get (once you get Dash past level 1) is also pretty cool.However, the game looks primitive, if functional, and the missions seem incredibly dull. Admittedly, I only did about 10 missions, but the environments weren't interesting and the objectives were overly simple. Enemy AI is awful. There's a blob that literally does nothing unless you run into it (it doesn't even move), and some kind of walking worm thing that you just stunlock by hitting it every few seconds. On top of that, all the enemies are bullet sponges.Any fun you get from the sense of running around at ludicrous speeds is undermined by the fact that all you really do is circle-strafe and pump shots into bullet-sponge enemies. If you stop moving, you die quickly. The sense of speed is appealing for a few minutes, but that's about it. There are no checkpoints in missions, and most of them involve a lot of running through bland landscapes.

Posted: March 29, 2015
-=Serious Review=--tl;dr reviewCaster is a perfect metaphor for the gaming industry as of writing this review. Caster represents an awesome idea that actually works and has only one real flaw with it, and that's how it's just too easy (Even so, that's eay to fix.) However, because of its unique style, it will not truly achieve the praise it needs. It's also unfortunate that the game has been essentially discontinued. That doesn't mean the community can't take it up on their own to continue it.-What is Caster? What genre does it fit into?Caster doesn't truly fit into the predefined genres we have today, the closest similar game would be Borderlands. It's definitely a shooting game, and also has some RPG elements. I guess we can call it an FPRPS (First Person Role-Playing Shooter.) It's third-person perspective and simple graphics also gives it that PS1/Arcade feel to it, and it's definitely appealing. Plus it easily gets 60+ fps on even the most burnt potato out there, so anyone can enjoy it.-StoryThere isn't much to the story, but the story that is there is enough... barely. All you're truly given is a name to the main enemies and some minor exposition. Basically, not a lot of text boxes.-GameplayThis is where Caster truly does shine. To start off, your character has free roam over wherever you are. As such you are given the ability to dash and super jump (which is a powerful double jump) to enhance the fun of it. With the base dash and jump, you're not moving very far or going very high, but as you upgrade you become more epic. Eventually you'll be dashing for longer distances, running on water, and even running on walls. I'll be damned if I could find another game that makes wall-running and shooting both fun and easy.When you start off, you'll only have your basic shooting "ability" "Pulse." It's not very strong starting out looking and behaving very similar to Mega Man's basic attack. It needs to be upgraded to become even better. Missions are where you earn the credits to upgrade this ability. And as you do more missions you'll gain access to more abilities, each with their unique-ness.Environment interaction. For a game off this size, it's incredible to have environments that are fully interactable. A lot of things can cause craters to form, from both you and enemies. If you super jump and fall long enough, you can leave a small crater and create a shockwave. Your basic shots can build craters too. You can even get an ability to create hills, to get bonuses underwater mainly. There's even one instance where enemies will try to stay underground and take pot shots at you.Enemies, however, is the only true point where the game doesn't shine. The enemies in Caster are way too easy. Upgrades for abilities just do massive amounts of damage, and enemies don't get adjusted for this in each level as you progress. Eventually, even on hard, you'll get to a point where you're just like: "That's cool, and now it's dead. Next level." It's a damn shame too, because adaptive enemies would pad out the gameplay much better than spreading them out. Too bad that'll never be fixed :c-tl;dr gameplaySonic the Hedgehog + Mega Man + Borderlands - Difficult AI = Caster-ModdingWhile I'm not truly a "Modder" (At the time of writing, at least) Caster looks way more than simple to mod. There is mod support from what I can tell at the time of writing this. I would also wager that this game would be a perfect start for getting into modding, as it's so simple and open to the idea of community-created content. Hell, why stop at making single-player campaigns? You could probably add some sort of multiplayer to this game easier than any other indie game on Steam. This might be where the game has a future, and it would be up to the community.

Posted: April 27, 2015
												A pleasant surprise, I bought this game only because of the trading cards, but this was actually fun to play. The main reason why is that this game feels like a really fresh and original PS1 game. The core elements of the game make it fun to mess around with.In particular once you start upgrading dash you start running around like sonic the hedgehog. Dashing is pretty versatile too, you can run up and along hills very easily.The main thing that makes the game fun is being able to morph the terrain, in particular you can increase or decrease the height of terrain (within limits) which makes this game so fresh.Some of the levels really take the core concepts to heart to create really unique missions.The only bad thing I can say about this game is the beginning is really weak and the game is short. There are community made levels, but I didn't bother with them. And with the game being so old I doubt the devs are actively working to finish the game.Weirdly, this game is probably one of the better purchases I've ever made.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												There's a lot to like here but unfortunately I can't recommend the game in the form it's in.  Right before the final mission of the second and final campaign map you get a "check the website for updates" alert.  I know there isn't much of a story here but this is worse than a bad ending, this just seems unfinished.  And given the length of time it's been out I doubt there's much chance we'll see an ending.Onto the good: it was fun while it lasted.  Nostalgia-inducing retro graphics.  Short, punchy missions.  Very fast paced.  Puts the 'Action' in 'Action Adventure'.  You get drawn in by the fluid gameplay, switching out weaponry to combat the different critters that come your way, sprinting up sheer cliffs, across water, leaping over mountains, all the while tossing huge amounts of colorful munitions at your beast alien foes.But then, bam, the rug is pulled from under you.  And all you can do is awkwardly roll your way back to the main menu, quit and uninstall.

												This is a kind of a bullet hell game,it has alot of energy blasts flying everywhere when you are fighting and thats really itThe graphics arent very great,it feel like n64....and the main male character looks like the kid from Quest64 too.But it makes up for it very well by build really fluid and feeling great to move around and fight.The music fits really well to the battle and style of the game,and it all works amazingly wellThe power ups you use to fight can also be used to change the land around you which is really fun and a neat idea.The enemies are kinda generic and are all pretty easy but the combat is still fun with the how short the game is kinda works in its favor where you dont really notice the repeating fightsI beat the game in about an hour,I didnt 100% every level but it still wouldnt add that much time to the overall playthrough,There is one level that i found to just be made to be annoying and bad,basically mixing terrible A.I. and weird terraforming power ups and it turns the enjoyable experience into something i hated and almost gave up the game but i wanted to give it a fair chance.(and plus the level is in the 2nd part of the game)Overall,this game was way above my expectations and i really enjoyed most of it(that one level i really hated) Play it for a short and fun time

Posted: March 29, 2015
												I bought this game for $.14, and for that amount of money it's worth it. The graphics are ridiculously dated. Older farts like me will remember the original "Jedi Knight" with an early 3D add-on card that looked amazing. We're talking mid-to-late 1990s here. Yes, this game looks worse than that.As much as I hate to admit it, as crappy as the graphical quality is, the game is actually kind of fun but not for prolonged amounts of time. It doesn't take much to build up your various characteristics (weapons, shield, speed, etc.) and you're not going to get a lot of gameplay out of it.Buy this game when it's available for less than $.50 and mess around with it until you get your cards. The game probably won't get played much more after that, though.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												I didn't actually expect this game to be at all decent when I got it, but I thought for $0.14 how could you go wrong.Well, nothing did go wrong in fact, and it turned out thatI actually liked the game long enough to get into it. I ended up maxing out every ability and reclaiming both areas before I quit even. It reminds me a little bit of Red Faction, in the sense that you can cause damage to your environment, or at least the ground (thats where the likeness ends though). It made me reminisce about older games that I spent time playing, mainly because of the very outdated sprites that were still fun nonethless to play with. It gives the game a very nice retro feel to it.Tl;dr - This is a fun little game that can be beat in an hour or two, and while its true that I probably wouldn't pay the normal price, if you can get this game when it's on sale and you don't mind old graphics, I would recommend this game.

Posted: June 8, 2016
												Whoa, i really got taken aback by this.Caster is game where you are sent on missions in restricted enviroments in order to blast bug-mosters.Let me be honest; the game is rough around the edges. If I were to nitpick, I could find a long list of failings: outdated low-poly graphics, paper-thin plot, weapon imbalances, short length, etc. But screw all that.This game is all about the game-play. In a nutshell, it is so delightful to run around and shoot things! Elecorn, the game developer, doubled down on capturing the essential controls and game-feel, making Caster an accessible, fast-paced action shooter, which really makes you feal at ease when playing. Traversing through the map is enjoyable, shooting the bright, colourful weapons is fun, and your shots can kill bugs as well as affect the landscape, making you at later levels feel really powerful with your mountain-levelling, monster-slaying wrist-blaster.Just don't expect something grandiose like a Witcher game, and are sure to have an entertaining diversion.PS. There are some solid mods/DLCs at the game's website, if you wanna kill some more time and bugs.
